awd_titl_txt: Engineering Interfaces for High-Performance Oxide Superconductor Nanocomposite Films
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Superconductors are materials that can carry electric currents without loss, which is one of the most exotic physical phenomena in nature and is described quantitatively by the superconducting critical current density Jc. Therefore, superconductivity offers applications such as quantum computing to meet future computing needs and restoring the reliability of the power grid alongside increasing its capacity and efficiency. The discovery of oxide high temperature superconductors (HTSs) provides possibilities for superconductors in applications at liquid nitrogen temperature and presents a fascinating research topic due to their unusual electronic structure and layered crystalline structures which gives profound effects on their physical properties, especially Jc. Raising Jc in HTSs has been the focus of world-wide efforts in the field of applied superconductivity. Growth of nanoscale artificial pinning centers (APCs) provides a powerful approach to raise Jc in nanocomposites, and the method can be directly implemented to large-scale HTS devices for commercialization. This project investigates the strained interfaces, the key driving force in strain-mediated self-assembly of APCs and the determining factor of the APC's pinning efficiency and hence Jc in nanocomposites. The goal is to achieve controllable APCs with precisely designed morphology, orientation, density, and interfaces. The scientific knowledge developed through this project will broadly impact future electronic and electrical applications. Nanoscale control of interfaces applies to computing, sensing, catalysis, and energy production/storage. The integrated modeling-synthesis-characterization approach can be extended to a range of nanocomposites beyond HTSs including ferroelectric, multiferroic, magnetoelectrics and semiconductors to produce novel and unprecedented properties. Both undergraduate and graduate students are gaining the cutting-edge research experience in preparation for careers in science and engineering. Students, especially those from underrepresented groups, are recruited through on campus programs (such as Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site and APS Bridge programs), collaborators and alumni. 

TECHNICAL DETAILS: This project focuses on understanding and manipulating interface strains towards controllable growth and high pinning efficiency of nanoscale artificial pinning centers (APCs) in REBa2Cu3O7 (RE-123, RE for rare earth elements Y, Gd, Sm, etc.), aiming at high critical current density (Jc) in a strong magnetic field (H) in the APC/RE-123 nanocomposites. The project has four topics. Topic 1 investigates the pinning efficiency of c-axis aligned one dimensional (1D) APCs, especially the effect of the strained interfaces on Jc and pinning force density Fp. Topic 2 explores schemes, particularly multilayered 1D nanocomposites by insertion of the Ca-substituted RE-123 spacers, for repairing the defective interfaces for enhanced pinning efficiency. Based on theoretical predictions, topic 3 searches for new 1D APCs with small diameters approaching the coherence length and self-repairing functionality. Topic 4 explores APCs of mixed morphologies for H-orientation independent Jc using microscopic control of the strain field in nanocomposites.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of the proposed research is to develop a material-by-design approach to achieve a precise control over (1) the microstructure of the nanoscale artificial pinning centers (APCs) in high temperature superconductor REBa2Cu3O7 (RE-123, RE for rare earth elements Y, Gd, Sm, etc) films or APC/RE-123 nanocomposite films through a thorough understanding of the strain-mediated microscopic growth mechanism of the APCs in the nanocomposite films; and (2) functionality (or pinning efficiency) of the APCs to enhance Jc approaching Jd and the pinning force density Fp=JcxH at high H fields to meet the specification of practical applications. The goal is to achieve high and H-orientation independent Jc in APC/RE-123 nanocomposites.

Four integrated themes were proposed originally and the specific scopes of the four themes are summarized in the following. Theme 1 will focus on understanding the pinning efficiency of 1D APCs, especially the effect of strained, defective interface of 1D APC/RE-123 on the Jc, Fp and Hmax of the APC/RE-123 nanocomposites. Theme 2 investigates the ML scheme for repair of the 1D APC/YBCO interface to reduce/eliminate the detrimental effect of the oxygen disorder at such an interface. Theme 3 explores new 1D APCs predicted by our simulation which may have smaller diameters ~ 2xa and self-repairing functionality on the APC/YBCO interface, both being critical towards stronger, and higher density correlated 1D APCs for higher Jc, Fp, and Hmax.  Theme 4 studies the 1D and 2D APC orientation phase diagrams to achieve understanding of the microscopic controlling mechanisms in their orientation at variable dopant concentrations via matrix/substrate interfacial strain or/and multilayer hetero-structures. In addition, doping of the secondary APCs to perturb the local strain and hence alter the 1D APCs morphology for 3D pinning landscape.  In the following, we describe the details of the proposed research.

The project has achieved an important understanding of the pinning efficiency of 1D APCs, especially confirmed that it is determined by their interface with RE-123 matrix and the quality of the interface crystallinity can impact the pinning efficiency (Jc, Fp, and Hmax) by orders of magnitude (Theme 1). This discovery is an important step towards creating schemes to resolve the interface issue stemming from strain-induced formation of defects. One scheme explored in the project is to insert two thin Ca-containing spacers of 5-15 nm in thickness into the APC/RE-123 nanocomposite films to form multilayered structure. This allows dynamic Ca diffusion along the tensile strained 1D APC/RE-123 interface as Ca diffusion channel into the RE-123 layers. The subsequent Ca/Cu replacement on the Cu-O atomic planes of the RE-123 leads to lattice expansion and hence reduction of the strain at the 1D APC/RE-123 interface. Consequently, the high-quality crystallinity is resumed at the interface, resulting dramatic improvement of pinning (Theme 2).  In Theme 3, prediction of new APC materials was achieved using strain-field simulations and a set of new candidates were obtained. In particular, considering the benefits of Ca on APC/RE-123 interface, several Ca-containing APC materials have been identified for experimental confirmation. Theme 4 evaluated several pinning landscapes based on mixed APC morphologies and optimal ones have been identified to yield high and isotropic pinning.

The key outcomes of this project include 1 issued US patent, 7 pending US patent application, >70 peer-reviewed publications generated including 10 invited book chapters/reviews. In addition, >40 presentations (~27 invited/plenary) were given by the PI and her group at conferences.

This project has provided training in a highly interactive and dynamic team-setting environment. This has multiple benefits to trainees including: 1) team-work experience and leadership development; 2) broad knowledge and research skills; and 3) interdisciplinary research approaches. Over the project period, the PI’s group has hosted a large number of researchers at different levels including 3 postdocs, 16 PhD students (7 finished during the project period and 9 current), 5 undergraduates and 3 high schoolers on research topics of thin films and devices, graphene fabrication and characterization, and functional ceramic dielectrics, respectively. 7 PhD dissertations were completed (one received honor) and they are employed both in US and across the world as university faculty, research staff in research institutions and US industry including Intel, Honeywell, Tower Semiconductors, etc. All undergraduate researchers have entered/or plan to enter PhD programs and all high school researchers are in colleges for STEM studies.    

This project’s outcome also includes a series education/outreach activities carried out by PI and her group, especially through a collaboration of KU National History Museum Education in development of online and hands-on activities for K-12 students/teachers and public. For example, the Science Shorts—a set of four mini animated videos about nanoscience, solar energy and electricity has now had more than 1,200,000 views at the Quarked! Adventures in the Subatomic Universe website (www.quarked.org), which continues to have visitors from more than 100 countries and had more than 150,000 unique visits each year.

 


Last Modified: 09/02/2024
Modified by: Judy Z Wu
